speech.speaker: EGLAMOUR
speech.line: The sun begins to gild the western sky;
And now it is about the very hour
That Silvia, at Friar Patrick's cell, should meet me.
She will not fail, for lovers break not hours,
Unless it be to come before their time;
So much they spur their expedition.
See where she comes.
Lady, a happy evening!

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour,
Out at the postern by the abbey-wall:
I fear I am attended by some spies.

speech.speaker: EGLAMOUR
speech.line: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;
If we recover that, we are sure enough.

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: O, sir, I find her milder than she was;
And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: What, that my leg is too long?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: No; that it is too little.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: I'll wear a boot, to make it somewhat rounder.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Aside But love will not be spurr'd to what
it loathes.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: What says she to my face?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: She says it is a fair one.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: Nay then, the wanton lies; my face is black.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is,
Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Aside 'Tis true; such pearls as put out
ladies' eyes;
For I had rather wink than look on them.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: How likes she my discourse?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Ill, when you talk of war.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Aside But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: What says she to my valour?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Aside She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: What says she to my birth?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: That you are well derived.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Aside True; from a gentleman to a fool.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: Considers she my possessions?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: O, ay; and pities them.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: Wherefore?

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Aside That such an ass should owe them.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: That they are out by lease.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Here comes the duke.

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: How now, Sir Proteus! how now, Thurio!
Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: Not I.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: Saw you my daughter?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Neither.

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: Why then,
She's fled unto that peasant Valentine;
And Eglamour is in her company.
'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both,
As he in penance wander'd through the forest;
Him he knew well, and guess'd that it was she,
But, being mask'd, he was not sure of it;
Besides, she did intend confession
At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not;
These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.
Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse,
But mount you presently and meet with me
Upon the rising of the mountain-foot
That leads towards Mantua, whither they are fled:
Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,
That flies her fortune when it follows her.
I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour
Than for the love of reckless Silvia.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: And I will follow, more for Silvia's love
Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: And I will follow, more to cross that love
Than hate for Silvia that is gone for love.

scene.title: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.

speech.speaker: First Outlaw
speech.line: Come, come,
Be patient; we must bring you to our captain.

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: A thousand more mischances than this one
Have learn'd me how to brook this patiently.

speech.speaker: Second Outlaw
speech.line: Come, bring her away.

speech.speaker: First Outlaw
speech.line: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

speech.speaker: Third Outlaw
speech.line: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,
But Moyses and Valerius follow him.
Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;
There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled;
The thicket is beset; he cannot 'scape.

speech.speaker: First Outlaw
speech.line: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave:
Fear not; he bears an honourable mind,
And will not use a woman lawlessly.

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!

scene.title: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: How use doth breed a habit in a man!
This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods,
I better brook than flourishing peopled towns:
Here can I sit alone, unseen of any,
And to the nightingale's complaining notes
Tune my distresses and record my woes.
O thou that dost inhabit in my breast,
Leave not the mansion so long tenantless,
Lest, growing ruinous, the building fall
And leave no memory of what it was!
Repair me with thy presence, Silvia;
Thou gentle nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain!
What halloing and what stir is this to-day?
These are my mates, that make their wills their law,
Have some unhappy passenger in chase.
They love me well; yet I have much to do
To keep them from uncivil outrages.
Withdraw thee, Valentine: who's this comes here?

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Madam, this service I have done for you,
Though you respect not aught your servant doth,
To hazard life and rescue you from him
That would have forced your honour and your love;
Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look;
A smaller boon than this I cannot beg
And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Aside How like a dream is this I see and hear!
Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: O miserable, unhappy that I am!

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came;
But by my coming I have made you happy.

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Aside And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: Had I been seized by a hungry lion,
I would have been a breakfast to the beast,
Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.
O, Heaven be judge how I love Valentine,
Whose life's as tender to me as my soul!
And full as much, for more there cannot be,
I do detest false perjured Proteus.
Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: What dangerous action, stood it next to death,
Would I not undergo for one calm look!
O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved,
When women cannot love where they're beloved!

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved.
Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love,
For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith
Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths
Descended into perjury, to love me.
Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two;
And that's far worse than none; better have none
Than plural faith which is too much by one:
Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: In love
Who respects friend?

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: All men but Proteus.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words
Can no way change you to a milder form,
I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end,
And love you 'gainst the nature of love,--force ye.

speech.speaker: SILVIA
speech.line: O heaven!

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: I'll force thee yield to my desire.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch,
Thou friend of an ill fashion!

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Valentine!

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love,
For such is a friend now; treacherous man!
Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye
Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say
I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.
Who should be trusted, when one's own right hand
Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus,
I am sorry I must never trust thee more,
But count the world a stranger for thy sake.
The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst,
'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: My shame and guilt confounds me.
Forgive me, Valentine: if hearty sorrow
Be a sufficient ransom for offence,
I tender 't here; I do as truly suffer
As e'er I did commit.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Then I am paid;
And once again I do receive thee honest.
Who by repentance is not satisfied
Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased.
By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased:
And, that my love may appear plain and free,
All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: O me unhappy!

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Look to the boy.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Why, boy! why, wag! how now! what's the matter?
Look up; speak.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ring
to Madam Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was never done.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Where is that ring, boy?

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Here 'tis; this is it.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: How! let me see:
Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook:
This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: But how camest thou by this ring? At my depart
I gave this unto Julia.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: And Julia herself did give it me;
And Julia herself hath brought it hither.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: How! Julia!

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths,
And entertain'd 'em deeply in her heart.
How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root!
O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush!
Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me
Such an immodest raiment, if shame live
In a disguise of love:
It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,
Women to change their shapes than men their minds.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Than men their minds! 'tis true.
O heaven! were man
But constant, he were perfect. That one error
Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins:
Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.
What is in Silvia's face, but I may spy
More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Come, come, a hand from either:
Let me be blest to make this happy close;
'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.

speech.speaker: PROTEUS
speech.line: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.

speech.speaker: JULIA
speech.line: And I mine.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO

speech.speaker: Outlaws
speech.line: A prize, a prize, a prize!

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Forbear, forbear, I say! it is my lord the duke.
Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced,
Banished Valentine.

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: Sir Valentine!

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Thurio, give back, or else embrace thy death;
Come not within the measure of my wrath;
Do not name Silvia thine; if once again,
Verona shall not hold thee. Here she stands;
Take but possession of her with a touch:
I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.

speech.speaker: THURIO
speech.line: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I;
I hold him but a fool that will endanger
His body for a girl that loves him not:
I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: The more degenerate and base art thou,
To make such means for her as thou hast done
And leave her on such slight conditions.
Now, by the honour of my ancestry,
I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,
And think thee worthy of an empress' love:
Know then, I here forget all former griefs,
Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,
Plead a new state in thy unrivall'd merit,
To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine,
Thou art a gentleman and well derived;
Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy.
I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake,
To grant one boom that I shall ask of you.

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: I grant it, for thine own, whate'er it be.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: These banish'd men that I have kept withal
Are men endued with worthy qualities:
Forgive them what they have committed here
And let them be recall'd from their exile:
They are reformed, civil, full of good
And fit for great employment, worthy lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee:
Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.
Come, let us go: we will include all jars
With triumphs, mirth and rare solemnity.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: And, as we walk along, I dare be bold
With our discourse to make your grace to smile.
What think you of this page, my lord?

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.

speech.speaker: DUKE
speech.line: What mean you by that saying?

speech.speaker: VALENTINE
speech.line: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along,
That you will wonder what hath fortuned.
Come, Proteus; 'tis your penance but to hear
The story of your loves discovered:
That done, our day of marriage shall be yours;
One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
